misconfigurations.scenario: Idle Load Balancers
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: A load balancer has had less than 100 requests per day for the last 7 days.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: consider deleting your load balancer.
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks your Elastic Load Balancing configuration for load balancers that are not actively used. Any load balancer that is configured accrues charges. If a load balancer has no associated back-end instances or if network traffic is severely limited, the load balancer is not being used effectively

misconfigurations.scenario: Idle Load Balancers
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: A load balancer has no active back-end instances.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: consider registering instances or deleting your load balancer.
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks your Elastic Load Balancing configuration for load balancers that are not actively used. Any load balancer that is configured accrues charges. If a load balancer has no associated back-end instances or if network traffic is severely limited, the load balancer is not being used effectively

misconfigurations.scenario: Amazon ElastiCache Reserved Node Optimization
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Optimizing the purchase of ElastiCache Reserved Nodes can help reduce costs
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: See the Cost Explorer page for more detailed recommendations, customization options (e.g. look-back period, payment option, etc.) and to purchase ElastiCache Reserved Nodes
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks your usage of ElastiCache and provides recommendations on purchase of Reserved Nodes to help reduce costs incurred from using ElastiCache On-Demand. AWS generates these recommendations by analyzing your On-Demand usage for the past 30 days. We then simulate every combination of reservations in the generated category of usage in order to identify the best number of each type of Reserved Node to purchase to maximize your savings. This check covers recommendations based on partial upfront payment option with 1-year or 3-year commitment. This check is not available to accounts linked in Consolidated Billing. Recommendations are only available for the Paying Account.

misconfigurations.scenario: pods OR nodes within cluster are not appropriately sized (artur to clarify)
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: workloads (cpu, memory, network IOPs, etc.) for the previous 14, 30, 90 days, multiplied by 1.4 are too large...
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: recommend the proper size for each pod

misconfigurations.scenario: users wants to automatically manage data storage tiers
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: s3 lifecycle manager is turned off; intelligent tiering is not enabled
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: turn on lifecycle manager

misconfigurations.scenario: S3 buckets storing infrequently accessed data in Standard storage class without lifecycle policies
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: S3 buckets with >30 days old objects in Standard storage class, no lifecycle policies configured, and low GET request rates
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Implement S3 Lifecycle policies to transition objects to S3 Standard-IA (30+ days), Intelligent-Tiering, Glacier (90+ days), or Deep Archive (180+ days)
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: S3 storage costs can be reduced by 30-60% by implementing lifecycle policies to automatically transition objects to appropriate storage classes. Standard-IA saves ~45% for infrequently accessed data (30+ days), Glacier saves ~77% for archival (90+ days), and Glacier Deep Archive saves ~95% for long-term retention (180+ days). S3 Intelligent-Tiering automatically optimizes costs by moving objects between tiers. Lifecycle policies are free to implement with no transition fees within the same region.
misconfigurations.notes: AWS Well-Architected Framework - Organizations can reduce S3 costs by 30-60% with proper lifecycle management

metadata.source: AWS Well-Architected Framework Cost Optimization Pillar 2025

misconfigurations.scenario: No CloudWatch anomaly detection configured to identify unexpected cost increases
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: AWS accounts lack CloudWatch anomaly detection alarms for billing metrics and service-specific cost anomalies
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Enable AWS Cost Anomaly Detection with ML-powered alerts, configure CloudWatch billing alarms, and integrate with SNS for proactive cost monitoring
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: AWS Cost Anomaly Detection uses machine learning to identify unusual spending patterns and alert teams before bills become excessive. Configure detection for services, accounts, and cost categories with custom thresholds. Set up CloudWatch billing alarms for absolute spend thresholds. Integrate with SNS/Slack for real-time notifications. Early detection prevents runaway costs from misconfigurations (e.g., unintended data transfers, EC2 instances in wrong regions, misconfigured Auto Scaling). Organizations report catching 85-95% of cost anomalies within 24 hours.
misconfigurations.notes: AWS Well-Architected Framework - Proactive cost monitoring prevents bill shock

metadata.source: AWS Well-Architected Framework Cost Optimization Pillar 2025

misconfigurations.scenario: CloudWatch Logs groups without retention policies accumulating costs indefinitely
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: CloudWatch Logs groups with "Never Expire" retention policy, or log data older than 90 days consuming significant storage
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Set appropriate retention periods (7, 14, 30, 90, or 180 days) based on compliance requirements, export old logs to S3 for long-term archival at 87% cost reduction
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: CloudWatch Logs charges $0.50/GB ingested and $0.03/GB-month for storage. Without retention policies, logs accumulate indefinitely. Most organizations only need 30-90 days of hot logs. Implementation: 1) Review log groups without retention policies, 2) Set retention based on compliance needs (30 days typical for non-production, 90+ for production), 3) Export logs older than retention period to S3 ($0.023/GB-month = 87% cheaper). One organization reduced logging costs from $1,200/month to $200/month by implementing 30-day retention plus S3 archival.
misconfigurations.notes: AWS Well-Architected Framework - CloudWatch Logs is frequently overlooked cost optimization opportunity

metadata.source: AWS Well-Architected Framework Cost Optimization Pillar 2025

misconfigurations.scenario: EMR (or other) cluster is used and task nodes are not utilizing spot instances
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: use spot instances
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: useful for high CPU but low Memory requirements; i.e. high processing requirement but low (or no) caching required

misconfigurations.scenario: Unassociated Elastic IP Addresses
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: An allocated Elastic IP address (EIP) is not associated with a running Amazon EC2 instance.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Associate the EIP with a running active instance, or release the unassociated EIP.
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks for Elastic IP addresses (EIPs) that are not associated with a running Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (Amazon EC2) instance. EIPs are static IP addresses designed for dynamic cloud computing. Unlike traditional static IP addresses, EIPs can mask the failure of an instance or Availability Zone by remapping a public IP address to another instance in your account. A nominal charge is imposed for an EIP that is not associated with a running instance.

misconfigurations.scenario: AWS resources lack cost allocation tags for tracking and attribution
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Resources exist without mandatory cost allocation tags (cost-center, project, owner, environment) preventing accurate chargeback and showback
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Implement organization-wide tagging schema with mandatory tags and use AWS Tag Editor or Tag Policies to enforce compliance
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: COST03-BP02: Without proper tagging, organizations cannot attribute costs to specific business units, projects, or applications. This prevents effective cost optimization, chargeback/showback, and financial accountability. Implement a consistent tagging schema including cost-center, project-id, owner, environment, and application tags. Use AWS Cost Categories to group costs, Tag Policies for governance, and Cost Explorer to analyze spending by tag dimensions.
misconfigurations.notes: AWS Well-Architected Framework COST03-BP02

metadata.source: AWS Well-Architected Framework Cost Optimization Pillar 2025

misconfigurations.scenario: Workloads with predictable steady-state usage lack Savings Plan or Reserved Instance coverage
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: On-Demand usage >40% for production workloads with consistent 24/7 runtime and predictable capacity requirements
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Purchase Compute Savings Plans or EC2 Instance Savings Plans to cover 60-80% of steady-state usage for up to 72% cost reduction
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Organizations paying On-Demand rates for predictable workloads miss significant savings opportunities. Savings Plans offer up to 72% discount vs On-Demand pricing with flexible commitment options. Analyze usage patterns with AWS Cost Explorer, target 60-80% coverage for steady-state workloads, and combine with On-Demand/Spot for variable capacity. Compute Savings Plans apply across EC2, Fargate, and Lambda; EC2 Instance Savings Plans offer higher discounts for specific instance families.
misconfigurations.notes: AWS Well-Architected Framework - Maintain 60-80% coverage leaving room for infrastructure evolution

metadata.source: AWS Well-Architected Framework Cost Optimization Pillar 2025

misconfigurations.scenario: No standardized decommissioning process resulting in abandoned resources accumulating costs
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Resources exist for completed projects, no defined process for identifying and removing unused infrastructure, or resources without ownership tags
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Implement COST04-BP02 decommissioning workflow: verify usage, document metadata, apply restrictive controls temporarily, then systematically remove resources
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: COST04-BP02: Without a formal decommissioning process, organizations accumulate unused resources from completed projects, departed employees, or abandoned experiments. Implement a standardized workflow: 1) Identify resources for decommission, 2) Verify with stakeholders, 3) Document metadata (IPs, configs), 4) Create backups if needed, 5) Apply restrictive policies for observation period, 6) Remove from automation/monitoring, 7) Delete resources. Include load balancers, EC2 instances, Auto Scaling groups, EBS volumes/snapshots, Elastic IPs, AMIs, and Elastic Beanstalk environments.
misconfigurations.notes: AWS Well-Architected Framework COST04-BP02 - High risk if not implemented

metadata.source: AWS Well-Architected Framework Cost Optimization Pillar 2025

misconfigurations.scenario: AWS accounts lack budgets and proactive spending controls resulting in cost overruns
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: No AWS Budgets configured for monthly spend, service costs, or Reserved Instance/Savings Plan utilization tracking
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Create AWS Budgets for total monthly spend (with 50%, 80%, 100% thresholds), service-specific budgets, and RI/SP coverage tracking with SNS notifications
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: COST02-BP05: AWS Budgets provide proactive cost controls through customizable alerts and thresholds. Create budgets for: 1) Total monthly spend with 50%/80%/100% alerts, 2) Individual service costs (EC2, S3, RDS), 3) Specific projects/teams using cost allocation tags, 4) RI/SP utilization and coverage. First 2 budgets are free; $0.02/day per additional budget. Integrate with SNS for email/Slack notifications. Advanced: Use Budget Actions to automatically apply IAM policies or SCPs when thresholds exceeded. Organizations with budgets reduce cost overruns by 60-80%.
misconfigurations.notes: AWS Well-Architected Framework COST02-BP05 - Implement cost controls

metadata.source: AWS Well-Architected Framework Cost Optimization Pillar 2025

misconfigurations.scenario: Organization lacks dedicated Cloud Financial Management team or FinOps function
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: No designated cost optimization owner, cost reviews occur reactively after bill shock, or finance and engineering teams operate in silos
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Establish COST01-BP01: Create Cloud Center of Excellence (CCoE) or FinOps team with dedicated ownership for cost optimization, reporting to both finance and engineering leadership
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: COST01-BP01: Organizations without dedicated cost management ownership experience 30-50% higher cloud costs. Establish a FinOps team (1-3 FTEs for organizations spending $1M+/year) responsible for: cost visibility, budget management, optimization recommendations, policy enforcement, and cultural enablement. Team should report to both CFO and CTO to bridge finance-technology gap. Key functions: monthly cost reviews, tagging enforcement, Savings Plan/RI management, cost allocation, showback/chargeback. ROI: FinOps teams typically drive 15-30% cost reduction within first year, far exceeding team cost.
misconfigurations.notes: AWS Well-Architected Framework COST01-BP01 - Foundation for all cost optimization

metadata.source: AWS Well-Architected Framework Cost Optimization Pillar 2025

misconfigurations.scenario: Workloads built with undifferentiated heavy lifting instead of leveraging managed services
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Self-managed databases, message queues, container orchestration, or caching layers when AWS managed service equivalents exist (RDS vs self-managed MySQL, MQ vs self-managed RabbitMQ, EKS vs self-managed K8s)
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Evaluate COST05-BP05: migrate to managed services (RDS, Aurora, ElastiCache, MQ, ECS/EKS, Lambda) to reduce operational overhead and often reduce total cost of ownership
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: COST05-BP05: Self-managed infrastructure requires EC2 instances, storage, licensing, patching, backups, monitoring, and engineering time. Managed services eliminate this overhead while often reducing costs. Example: Self-managed PostgreSQL on r5.2xlarge ($0.504/hr * 730hr = $368/month) + EBS ($50) + engineering time ($500/month) = $918/month vs RDS db.r5.2xlarge = $584/month (36% savings). Additional managed service benefits: automatic backups, patching, high availability, scalability. Evaluate migration for: databases (→ RDS/Aurora), caching (→ ElastiCache), message queues (→ SQS/SNS/MQ), containers (→ ECS/EKS/Fargate).
misconfigurations.notes: AWS Well-Architected Framework COST05-BP05 - Managed services reduce TCO

metadata.source: AWS Well-Architected Framework Cost Optimization Pillar 2025

misconfigurations.scenario: Workloads deployed without upfront cost modeling leading to budget overruns
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: New projects deployed without cost estimates, actual costs exceed projections by >30%, or architectural decisions made without cost analysis
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Implement COST06-BP01: perform cost modeling using AWS Pricing Calculator before deployment, establish cost targets per workload, validate assumptions with pilots
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: COST06-BP01: Organizations deploying without cost modeling experience 25-40% cost overruns. Use AWS Pricing Calculator to model costs across multiple architecture options before committing. Include: compute, storage, data transfer, managed services, and reserved capacity discounts. Compare options: serverless vs containers vs EC2, single-region vs multi-region, GP2 vs GP3 storage. Validate with proof-of-concept deployments. Establish cost per transaction/user/request metrics. Review monthly to track actuals vs model. Iterate architecture based on cost data. Example: modeling revealed serverless option was 60% cheaper than container option for variable traffic workload.
misconfigurations.notes: AWS Well-Architected Framework COST06-BP01 - Model before building

metadata.source: AWS Well-Architected Framework Cost Optimization Pillar 2025

misconfigurations.scenario: Engineering teams lack cost awareness and accountability for cloud spending
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Developers unaware of resource costs, no cost metrics in team dashboards, cost optimization not included in performance reviews or sprint planning
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Establish COST01-BP08: create cost-aware culture by including cost metrics in engineering dashboards, making cost part of architecture reviews, recognizing cost optimization achievements
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: COST01-BP08: Engineering teams make architecture decisions impacting 80% of cloud costs, yet often lack cost visibility. Build cost-aware culture: 1) Display cost dashboards in team spaces showing daily spend trends, 2) Include cost in sprint retrospectives and architecture reviews, 3) Implement cost per feature/transaction metrics, 4) Gamify optimization with team competitions and recognition, 5) Provide training on cost-effective architecture patterns. Integrate cost into CI/CD with tools showing estimated cost impact of changes. Organizations with strong cost culture achieve 20-35% lower costs while maintaining innovation velocity.
misconfigurations.notes: AWS Well-Architected Framework COST01-BP08 - Culture drives sustainable optimization

metadata.source: AWS Well-Architected Framework Cost Optimization Pillar 2025

misconfigurations.scenario: Resources not leveraging shared infrastructure leading to resource sprawl and duplication
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Each application team deploying separate NAT Gateways, Transit Gateways, VPCs, or shared services instead of using centralized shared resources
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Implement COST06-BP04: establish shared service model for common infrastructure (centralized NAT Gateways, Transit Gateway, VPC, monitoring, security tools) with cost allocation via tags
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: COST06-BP04: Independent teams deploying duplicate infrastructure waste 40-60% on shared services. Implement shared service model: 1) Centralized networking (shared VPC with Transit Gateway, NAT Gateways), 2) Shared security tools (GuardDuty, Security Hub per organization vs per account), 3) Centralized monitoring (single CloudWatch/DataDog instance), 4) Shared CI/CD infrastructure. Use cost allocation tags for chargeback. Example: 20 teams each with NAT Gateway ($1,080/year) = $21,600/year vs centralized NAT Gateways with sharing = $3,240/year (85% savings). AWS Organizations enables cross-account resource sharing.
misconfigurations.notes: AWS Well-Architected Framework COST06-BP04 - Shared resources reduce duplication

metadata.source: AWS Well-Architected Framework Cost Optimization Pillar 2025

misconfigurations.scenario: Amazon Redshift Reserved Node Optimization
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Optimizing the purchase of Redshift Reserved Nodes can help reduce costs.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: See the Cost Explorer page for more detailed recommendations, customization options (e.g. look-back period, payment option, etc.) and to purchase Redshift Reserved Nodes
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks your usage of Redshift and provides recommendations on purchase of Reserved Nodes to help reduce costs incurred from using Redshift On-Demand. AWS generates these recommendations by analyzing your On-Demand usage for the past 30 days. We then simulate every combination of reservations in the generated category of usage in order to identify the best number of each type of Reserved Nodes to purchase to maximize your savings. This check covers recommendations based on partial upfront payment option with 1-year or 3-year commitment. This check is not available to accounts linked in Consolidated Billing. Recommendations are only available for the Paying Account.

misconfigurations.scenario: Underutilized Amazon Redshift Clusters
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: A running cluster has not had a connection in the last 7 days.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Consider shutting down the cluster and taking a final snapshot, or downsizing the cluster.
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks your Amazon Redshift configuration for clusters that appear to be underutilized. If an Amazon Redshift cluster has not had a connection for a prolonged period of time or is using a low amount of CPU, you can use lower-cost options such as downsizing the cluster or shutting down the cluster and taking a final snapshot. Final snapshots are retained even after you delete your cluster.
misconfigurations.notes: can beat our aws recommendations by determining which path is the correct path, and, if resizing is optimal, to which size

misconfigurations.scenario: Underutilized Amazon Redshift Clusters
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: A running cluster had less than 5% cluster-wide average CPU utilization for 99% of the last 7 days.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Consider shutting down the cluster and taking a final snapshot, or downsizing the cluster.
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks your Amazon Redshift configuration for clusters that appear to be underutilized. If an Amazon Redshift cluster has not had a connection for a prolonged period of time or is using a low amount of CPU, you can use lower-cost options such as downsizing the cluster or shutting down the cluster and taking a final snapshot. Final snapshots are retained even after you delete your cluster.
misconfigurations.notes: can beat our aws recommendations by determining which path is the correct path, and, if resizing is optimal, to which size

misconfigurations.scenario: Amazon EC2 Reserved Instance Lease Expiration
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: The Reserved Instance lease expires in less than 30 days.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Consider purchasing a new Reserved Instance to replace the one that is nearing the end of its term. For more information
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks for Amazon EC2 Reserved Instances that are scheduled to expire within the next 30 days or have expired in the preceding 30 days. Reserved Instances do not renew automatically; you can continue using an EC2 instance covered by the reservation without interruption, but you will be charged On-Demand rates. New Reserved Instances can have the same parameters as the expired ones, or you can purchase Reserved Instances with different parameters. The estimated monthly savings we show is the difference between the On-Demand and Reserved Instance rates for the same instance type.

misconfigurations.scenario: user has unattached or unused volumes
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: volumes are not attached to instances and have little to no activity
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: delete volumes
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks Amazon Elastic Block Store (Amazon EBS) volume configurations and warns when volumes appear to be underused. Charges begin when a volume is created. If a volume remains unattached or has very low write activity (excluding boot volumes) for a period of time, the volume is probably not being used.

misconfigurations.scenario: user has instances that are not being used regularly
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: cpu utilization of instances is below threshold
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: stop or terminate instance
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: tagging strategies could also be recommended to improve the general "intelligence" of the recommendations; Checks the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (Amazon EC2) instances that were running at any time during the last 14 days and alerts you if the daily CPU utilization was 10% or less and network I/O was 5 MB or less on 4 or more days. Running instances generate hourly usage charges. Although some scenarios can result in low utilization by design, you can often lower your costs by managing the number and size of your instances.

misconfigurations.scenario: user has already reduced waste, has a deep understanding of their future compute usage requirements, and wants to save money on their instance usage rates going forward
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: boto recommends "reserved instances" and the user has already gone through a "waste reduction" process"
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: purchase reserved instances
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: make sure to prompt the user, ensuring they have already maximized their savings by reducing waste, before recommending a RI plan.

misconfigurations.scenario: user has already reduced waste, has a good understanding of their future compute usage requirements, and wants to save money on their instance usage rates going forward
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: boto recommends "ec2 level savings plans" and the user has already gone through a "waste reduction" process"
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: purchase savings plan at ec2 level
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: make sure to prompt the user, ensuring they have already maximized their savings by reducing waste, before recommending a savings plan

misconfigurations.scenario: user has already reduced waste, has an okay understanding of their future compute usage requirements, and wants to save money on their instance usage rates going forward
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: boto recommends "ec2 level savings plans" and the user has already gone through a "waste reduction" process"
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: purchase general savings plan
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: make sure to prompt the user, ensuring they have already maximized their savings by reducing waste, before recommending a savings plan: Checks your usage of EC2, Fargate, and Lambda over the last 30 days and provides Savings Plan purchase recommendations, which allows you to commit to a consistent usage amount measured in $/hour for a one or three year term in exchange for discounted rates. These are sourced from AWS Cost Explorer which can be used to get more detailed recommendation information, or to purchase a savings plan. These recommendations should be considered an alternative to your RI recommendations and choosing to act fully on both sets of recommendations would likely lead to over commitment.

misconfigurations.scenario: user wants to be notified when/if their reserved instance lease is going to expire
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: The Reserved Instance lease is set to expire in the preceding 30 days
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Consider purchasing a new Reserved Instance to replace the one that is nearing the end of its term. For more information
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks for Amazon EC2 Reserved Instances that are scheduled to expire within the next 30 days or have expired in the preceding 30 days. Reserved Instances do not renew automatically; you can continue using an EC2 instance covered by the reservation without interruption, but you will be charged On-Demand rates. New Reserved Instances can have the same parameters as the expired ones, or you can purchase Reserved Instances with different parameters. The estimated monthly savings we show is the difference between the On-Demand and Reserved Instance rates for the same instance type.

misconfigurations.scenario: user wants to ensure instances are only on when needed (used during business hours, during a jobs runtime schedule, etc.)
misconfigurations.alert_criteria:
- tag(s) denote the instance as a "workday" instance and/or 
- the instance is only active for predictable times throughout the day
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: use tags to specify active hours and create a lambda function to hibernate ec2 instance when outside of tagged hours
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: ec2s are only used during specified hours; usually during regular business hours or when attached to a job

misconfigurations.scenario: Idle Amazon EC2 Instance
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: An instance had less than 5% daily average CPU utilization and 5 MB or less network I/O on at least 4 of the previous 14 days.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: stop or terminate instance
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud (Amazon EC2) instances that were running at any time during the last 14 days and alerts you if the daily CPU utilization was 5% or less and network I/O was 5 MB or less on 4 or more days. Running instances generate hourly usage charges. Although some scenarios can result in low utilization by design, you can often lower your costs by managing the number and size of your instances.

misconfigurations.scenario: EC2 instances running with very low CPU utilization indicating rightsizing opportunity
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: EC2 instances with CPU utilization <= 2% over the past 14 days or consistent usage below 10% during business hours
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Use AWS Compute Optimizer and Cost Explorer rightsizing recommendations to downsize or terminate idle instances
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Idle and underutilized EC2 instances represent immediate cost savings opportunities. Instances with consistently low CPU usage (especially below 2%) should be evaluated for termination or downsizing to smaller instance types. Use AWS Compute Optimizer for ML-powered rightsizing recommendations, AWS Cost Explorer for utilization analysis, and CloudWatch for detailed metrics. Start with development/test environments to minimize risk. Potential savings of 30-60% for rightsized instances.
misconfigurations.notes: AWS Well-Architected Framework - Start rightsizing with idle resources as they represent highest savings

metadata.source: AWS Well-Architected Framework Cost Optimization Pillar 2025

misconfigurations.scenario: Fault-tolerant and flexible workloads not leveraging EC2 Spot Instances for cost savings
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Batch processing, containerized applications, CI/CD, or stateless workloads running 100% On-Demand without Spot Instance usage
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Implement Spot Instances for eligible workloads using Spot Fleet, Auto Scaling groups with mixed instances, or ECS/EKS Spot capacity
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Spot Instances offer up to 90% savings vs On-Demand pricing for fault-tolerant workloads. Ideal use cases include batch processing, data analysis, containerized applications, CI/CD pipelines, web servers with load balancers, and development/test environments. Use Spot Fleet or Auto Scaling with mixed instance types for diversification. Implement graceful handling of 2-minute termination notices. Not suitable for databases or stateful applications without proper architecture.
misconfigurations.notes: AWS Well-Architected Framework - Spot diversification reduces interruption risk

metadata.source: AWS Well-Architected Framework Cost Optimization Pillar 2025

misconfigurations.scenario: Development and test environments running 24/7 without scheduled shutdown during non-business hours
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: EC2 instances tagged as dev/test/staging running continuously outside business hours (nights, weekends) with no active connections
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Implement AWS Instance Scheduler or Lambda-based automation to stop non-production instances during non-business hours (achieving 65-75% runtime reduction)
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: COST09-BP03: Development and test environments rarely need 24/7 availability. Implementing scheduled stop/start (e.g., 8am-6pm weekdays only) reduces runtime by 65-75%, directly cutting compute costs. Use AWS Instance Scheduler for centralized management across accounts, or Lambda with EventBridge for custom schedules. Include RDS databases, Redshift clusters, and other stoppable resources. Ensure proper tagging (environment=dev/test) for automation. Monthly savings: ~$500-2000 per medium-sized dev environment.
misconfigurations.notes: AWS Well-Architected Framework COST09-BP03 - Simple but highly effective cost optimization

metadata.source: AWS Well-Architected Framework Cost Optimization Pillar 2025

misconfigurations.scenario: Production workloads without Auto Scaling unable to optimize costs during variable demand
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: EC2 workloads with variable traffic patterns running fixed capacity without Auto Scaling, or Auto Scaling groups using only simple scaling without target tracking
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Configure AWS Auto Scaling with target tracking policies for CPU/memory, implement predictive scaling for known patterns, and use scheduled scaling for recurring events
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: COST09-BP03: Auto Scaling ensures you only pay for needed capacity while maintaining performance. Use target tracking for automatic scaling based on metrics (e.g., CPU 50%), predictive scaling for traffic patterns (pre-scaling before daily spikes), and scheduled scaling for known events. Combine with mixed instance types (On-Demand + Spot) for additional savings. Implement across EC2, ECS, DynamoDB, and Aurora. Properly configured Auto Scaling reduces costs by 20-40% while improving availability.
misconfigurations.notes: AWS Well-Architected Framework COST09-BP03 - Auto Scaling is fundamental to cloud cost optimization

metadata.source: AWS Well-Architected Framework Cost Optimization Pillar 2025

misconfigurations.scenario: AWS Lambda Functions with Excessive Timeouts
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Functions where > 10% of invocations end in an error due to a timeout on any given day within the last 7 days.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: increase the timeout setting for the function.
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks for Lambda functions with high timeout rates that may result in high cost. Lambda charges based on execution time for your function and number of requests for your function. Function timeouts result in function errors that may cause retries that incur additional request and execution time charges. For more information, see Monitoring and troubleshooting Lambda applications.

misconfigurations.scenario: AWS Lambda Functions with High Error Rates
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Functions where > 10% of invocations end in error on any given day within the last 7 days
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Consider the following guidelines to reduce errors. Function errors include errors returned by the function's code and errors returned by the function's runtime. To help you troubleshoot Lambda errors, Lambda integrates with services like Amazon CloudWatch and AWS X-Ray. You can use a combination of logs, metrics, alarms, and X-ray tracing to quickly detect and identify issues in your function code, API, or other resources that support your application.
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks for Lambda functions with high error rates that may result in high cost. Lambda charges based on the number of requests and aggregate execution time for your function. Function errors may cause retries that incur additional charges. Consider the following guidelines to reduce errors. Function errors include errors returned by the function's code and errors returned by the function's runtime. To help you troubleshoot Lambda errors, Lambda integrates with services like Amazon CloudWatch and AWS X-Ray. You can use a combination of logs, metrics, alarms, and X-ray tracing to quickly detect and identify issues in your function code, API, or other resources that support your application.

misconfigurations.scenario: Lambda functions with provisioned concurrency enabled for workloads with variable or infrequent traffic
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Lambda functions with provisioned concurrency >0, or provisioned concurrency utilization <50% over 30 days, or non-latency-sensitive workloads using provisioned concurrency
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Evaluate necessity of provisioned concurrency - disable for non-latency-sensitive workloads, use Application Auto Scaling for provisioned concurrency to match traffic patterns, or migrate to on-demand invocation
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Lambda provisioned concurrency eliminates cold starts but costs 10-20x more than on-demand ($0.000009722/GB-second provisioned vs $0.0000166667/GB-second on-demand). Only justified for: 1) latency-sensitive user-facing APIs requiring <50ms, 2) consistently high traffic. Most workloads should use on-demand. If provisioned concurrency needed: use Application Auto Scaling to schedule (disable nights/weekends), or scale based on traffic. Example: Function with 1GB memory, 100 provisioned concurrency 24/7 = $700/month vs on-demand for same invocations = $50/month. Audit provisioned concurrency monthly for utilization.
misconfigurations.notes: AWS Well-Architected Framework - Provisioned concurrency often over-used due to cold start concerns

metadata.source: AWS Well-Architected Framework Cost Optimization Pillar 2025

misconfigurations.scenario: Amazon Relational Database Service (RDS) Reserved Instance Optimization
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Optimizing the purchase of RDS Reserved Instances can help reduce costs.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: See the Cost Explorer page for more detailed recommendations, customization options (e.g. look-back period, payment option, etc.) and to purchase RDS Reserved Instances.
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks your usage of RDS and provides recommendations on purchase of Reserved Instances to help reduce costs incurred from using RDS On-Demand. AWS generates these recommendations by analyzing your On-Demand usage for the past 30 days. We then simulate every combination of reservations in the generated category of usage in order to identify the best number of each type of Reserved Instance to purchase to maximize your savings. This check covers recommendations based on partial upfront payment option with 1-year or 3-year commitment. This check is not available to accounts linked in Consolidated Billing. Recommendations are only available for the Paying Account.

misconfigurations.scenario: Amazon RDS Idle DB Instances
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: An active DB instance has not had a connection in the last 7 days.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Consider taking a snapshot of the idle DB instance and then either stopping it or deleting it. Stopping the DB instance removes some of the costs for it, but does not remove storage costs. A stopped instance keeps all automated backups based upon the configured retention period. Stopping a DB instance usually incurs additional costs when compared to deleting the instance and then retaining only the final snapshot
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks the configuration of your Amazon Relational Database Service (Amazon RDS) for any DB instances that appear to be idle. If a DB instance has not had a connection for a prolonged period of time, you can delete the instance to reduce costs. If persistent storage is needed for data on the instance, you can use lower-cost options such as taking and retaining a DB snapshot. Manually created DB snapshots are retained until you delete them. Data for Amazon RDS instances created in the Asia Pacific (Seoul) region (sa-east-1) is not available. We are working to fix this issue as soon as possible

misconfigurations.scenario: RDS instances with over-provisioned storage capacity without auto-scaling enabled
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: RDS instances with <40% storage utilization, or storage manually increased multiple times, or auto-scaling not enabled
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Enable RDS Storage Auto Scaling with appropriate maximum storage threshold to automatically scale storage as needed, reducing over-provisioning waste
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: RDS storage is billed based on provisioned capacity, not actual usage. Organizations often over-provision (e.g., 1TB when only 200GB used) to avoid manual scaling operations. RDS Storage Auto Scaling automatically increases storage capacity when free space falls below 10% or 5GB threshold, preventing over-provisioning. Configure maximum storage limit based on anticipated growth. Supports GP2, GP3, and Provisioned IOPS storage. Scaling occurs with zero downtime. Typical savings: 30-50% of RDS storage costs by right-sizing initial allocation.
misconfigurations.notes: AWS Well-Architected Framework COST06 - Right-size RDS storage dynamically

metadata.source: AWS Well-Architected Framework Cost Optimization Pillar 2025

misconfigurations.scenario: RDS instances using GP2 storage instead of cost-effective GP3 storage type
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: RDS instances with gp2 storage type, especially those with low IOPS requirements (<3000 IOPS)
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Migrate RDS storage from GP2 to GP3 for 20% cost savings with same or better performance, using AWS console or modify-db-instance CLI command
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: GP3 storage offers 20% lower cost than GP2 with better baseline performance (3000 IOPS and 125 MB/s regardless of size vs GP2 performance scaling with size). GP3 pricing: $0.08/GB-month vs GP2 $0.10/GB-month. Migration is online with no downtime for most engines. GP3 allows independent IOPS and throughput provisioning (cost-effective for workloads needing high throughput but not high IOPS). Best candidates: databases >100GB where GP2 over-provisions performance. Calculate savings: (current_storage_GB * $0.02) * 12 months.
misconfigurations.notes: AWS Well-Architected Framework COST05 - GP3 is newer, faster, and 20% cheaper than GP2

metadata.source: AWS Well-Architected Framework Cost Optimization Pillar 2025

misconfigurations.scenario: user wants to remove or update inactive tasks
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: ecs task definition set to inactive status
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: delete or update task

misconfigurations.scenario: user needs to have an index of resources across regions they can search for
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: resource explorer is not enabled
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: enable resource explorer

misconfigurations.scenario: High data transfer costs from cross-region or internet data egress without optimization
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Significant data transfer charges from cross-region transfers, CloudFront not used for content delivery, or compute/storage in different regions
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Use CloudFront for content delivery (free S3-to-CloudFront transfer), co-locate resources in same region, use VPC endpoints, and PrivateLink for AWS service access
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Data transfer costs can represent 10-20% of AWS bills when not optimized. Key strategies: 1) Use CloudFront for content delivery (data transfer from S3 to CloudFront is free), 2) Keep compute and storage in same region/AZ, 3) Use VPC endpoints for S3/DynamoDB to avoid internet gateway charges, 4) Leverage AWS PrivateLink for service-to-service communication, 5) Use S3 Transfer Acceleration selectively. Cross-region transfers cost $0.02/GB while same-region is free.
misconfigurations.notes: AWS Well-Architected Framework - Data transfer optimization

metadata.source: AWS Well-Architected Framework Cost Optimization Pillar 2025

misconfigurations.scenario: NAT Gateway incurring high costs from cross-AZ data transfer and AWS service traffic
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: NAT Gateway data processing charges >$100/month, or traffic to S3/DynamoDB/other AWS services routing through NAT Gateway instead of VPC endpoints
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Deploy VPC endpoints for S3 and DynamoDB (free), use Interface VPC endpoints for other AWS services, ensure NAT Gateway per AZ to avoid cross-AZ charges, review VPC Flow Logs to identify optimization opportunities
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: NAT Gateways charge $0.045/GB for data processing plus hourly fees ($0.045/hour). Major cost drivers: 1) Cross-AZ traffic ($0.01/GB additional), 2) AWS service traffic (S3, DynamoDB) that could use free VPC endpoints, 3) Multiple idle NAT Gateways. Solution: Deploy VPC endpoints for S3/DynamoDB (free data transfer), use Interface endpoints for other services, deploy one NAT Gateway per AZ to eliminate cross-AZ charges. Use VPC Flow Logs temporarily to analyze traffic patterns. Typical savings: 40-60% of NAT Gateway costs.
misconfigurations.notes: AWS Well-Architected Framework COST08 - NAT Gateway is often the #1 networking cost driver

metadata.source: AWS Well-Architected Framework Cost Optimization Pillar 2025

misconfigurations.scenario: Amazon Elasticsearch Reserved Instance Optimization
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: Optimizing the purchase of Elasticsearch Reserved Instances can help reduce costs.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: See the Cost Explorer page for more detailed recommendations, customization options (e.g. look-back period, payment option, etc.) and to purchase Elasticsearch Reserved Instances.
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks your usage of Elasticsearch and provides recommendations on purchase of Reserved Instances to help reduce costs incurred from using Elasticsearch On-Demand. AWS generates these recommendations by analyzing your On-Demand usage for the past 30 days. We then simulate every combination of reservations in the generated category of usage in order to identify the best number of each type of Reserved Instance to purchase to maximize your savings. This check covers recommendations based on partial upfront payment option with 1-year or 3-year commitment. This check is not available to accounts linked in Consolidated Billing. Recommendations are only available for the Paying Account.

misconfigurations.scenario: Amazon Route 53 Latency Resource Record Sets
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: resources exist in multiple regions and only one latency resource record set is configured for a particular domain name.
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: define a latency resource record set for each region
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: Checks for Amazon Route 53 latency record sets that are configured inefficiently. To allow Amazon Route 53 to route queries to the region with the lowest network latency, you should create latency resource record sets for a particular domain name (such as example.com) in different regions. If you create only one latency resource record set for a domain name, all queries are routed to one region, and you pay extra for latency-based routing without getting the benefits. Hosted zones created by AWS services won’t appear in your check results.

misconfigurations.scenario: user wants to ensure that only necessary / needed snapshots are available for use
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: if snapshot is older than seven days and/or is older than another snapshot made from an identical volume, then recommend deletion
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: delete snapshot

misconfigurations.scenario: user wants to ensure ebs volumes are deleted when an instance is terminated
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: "delete on termination" flag on instances is set to false
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: set "delete on termination" flag to true (enable automatic deletion upon instance termination)

misconfigurations.scenario: Orphaned EBS snapshots and AMIs consuming storage costs after source volumes deleted
misconfigurations.alert_criteria: EBS snapshots exist where source volume has been deleted, or AMIs registered without associated running instances for 90+ days
misconfigurations.recommendation_action: Use AWS Data Lifecycle Manager to automate snapshot retention policies and identify/delete orphaned snapshots and unused AMIs
misconfigurations.recommendation_description_detailed: COST04-BP05: Orphaned snapshots accumulate when instances are terminated without cleanup processes. These snapshots incur storage costs (~$0.05/GB-month) indefinitely. Implement AWS Data Lifecycle Manager for automated snapshot creation/deletion policies. Identify orphaned snapshots by comparing snapshot volume IDs against active volumes. Review AMIs older than 90 days and deregister unused images along with associated snapshots. Typical organizations can reduce snapshot costs by 40-70% through proper lifecycle management.
misconfigurations.notes: AWS Well-Architected Framework COST04-BP05 - Enforce data retention policies

metadata.source: AWS Well-Architected Framework Cost Optimization Pillar 2025
